Once hailed as among the finest actors of his generation, Blake became better known as the defendant in a real-life murder story more bizarre than any in which he acted. He went from acclaim for his acting to notoriety when he was tried and acquitted in the killing of his wife, Bakley, who died outside a Studio City restaurant on May 4, 2001. "He spent the last few years listening to jazz music and playing his guitar and watching classic movies." His last credit was in the David Lynch thriller "Lost Highway," where he starred alongside Bill Pullman, Patricia Arquette and Henry Rollins.His niece, Noreen Austin, confirmed his cause of death was “long-term heart disease,” according to The New York Times. Blake was a regular in the “Our Gang” film comedies, which he started at the age of 5. One of his most celebrated roles was playing mass murderer Perry Smith in the 1967 movie “In Cold Blood,” an adaptation of novelist Truman Capote’s book. Blake was also known for being acquitted of the murder of his wife, Bonny Lee Bakley, who was found dead in his car from a gunshot wound to the head in May 2001. He “pleaded not guilty to all charges.” However, the stuntmen testified during the 2005 murder trial that they were indeed solicited by Blake to kill his wife. Ultimately, the jury decided the prosecutors did not have sufficient evidence to prove he was guilty. In interviews after the trial, jurors also claimed the stuntmen were not believable because they were drug addicts, which they admitted. After the murder, her father continued to maintain his innocence, but Rose Lenore Blake believed it felt “useless” for her “to have an opinion about it.”Robert Blake daughter Rose Lenore was only 11 months old when her mother was fatally shot. Begin story:

Robert Blake, Star of “In Cold Blood” and “Baretta”, Dies at Age 89

Robert Blake, an American actor who achieved fame for his roles in movies like “In Cold Blood” and the TV series “Baretta”, has died at the age of 89. His manager, Selena, confirmed the news of his passing on March 9, 2023, in Los Angeles, California. 

Once hailed as among the finest actors of his generation, Blake became better known as the defendant in a real-life murder story more bizarre than any in which he acted. He went from acclaim for his acting to notoriety when he was tried and acquitted in the killing of his wife, Bonny Lee Bakley, who died outside a Studio City restaurant on May 4, 2001. 

Blake’s daughter, Rose Lenore Blake, previously stated that she didn’t want to know if her father had shot and killed her mother. However, in 2019, she spoke to the media for the first time about her childhood and reconnecting with her father years after her mother’s tragic death. Robert’s daughter, who was only 11 months old when her mother was fatally shot, recalled being photographed by the paparazzi while cheering at her high school. 

“He spent the last few years listening to jazz music and playing his guitar and watching classic movies,” said his niece, Noreen Austin, who confirmed his cause of death was “long-term heart disease,” according to The New York Times. 

Blake was one of the first child actors to successfully transition to adult roles, which led to a long and varied career in Hollywood. He was a regular in the “Our Gang” film comedies, which he started at the age of 5. One of his most celebrated roles was playing mass murderer Perry Smith in the 1967 movie “In Cold Blood,” an adaptation of novelist Truman Capote’s book. 

Blake’s last credit was in the David Lynch thriller “Lost Highway,” where he starred alongside Bill Pullman, Patricia Arquette, and Henry Rollins. He was once hailed as a successful actor, earning numerous accolades, but his off-screen drama overshadowed that success. In 2005, he was found liable for his wife's wrongful death in a civil lawsuit brought against him by Bakley's children. 

After Bakley’s death, her daughter, Daiane Sodre, created an app to help people track down the truth about the case. As she said in a previous interview, “I want accuracy to be the most important thing, because a lot of people believe what they see in Hollywood movies, and the Hollywood portrayal is usually wrong.” 

Rose Lenore Blake, who was 19 at the time of the interview, believed it felt “useless” for her “to have an opinion about” her mother’s death. She was raised by her half-sister, Delinah, and her husband in Sherman Oaks. 

In interviews after the trial, jurors also claimed the two stuntmen who testified against Blake, claiming he solicited them to kill his wife, were not believable because they were drug addicts, which they admitted. Ultimately, the jury decided the prosecutors did not have sufficient evidence to prove he was guilty. 

Blake will always be remembered for his various roles in movies and television series, and people have been sharing their condolences with his family and friends. His legacy in Hollywood is a mixed one, but the talent he showcased in film and TV will continue to be celebrated.
